Investing in foreign countries requires knowledge of Bilateral Trade & Investment Treaties (BITs). My Swiss Partners & I have financed over 100 projects in developing countries. Seventy percent were very successful, the balance yield average returns.

Our best project was in Ukraine. We invested $35 million and our Ukrainian Partners $20 million. Under the BIT we managed to have 80% of the ownership outside Ukraine. The technology transfers were also under the BIT.

At the end of ten years, our market share was over 70%. Our exit strategy came into play when a major player acquired the Project for $600 million.

Project financing utilizes cash-on-cash investing. The economic model needs to show that the Project can generate enough free cash flow to justify the investment.

When Management is in the hands of skilled veterans, the operations work well. In addition we need to transfer technology (equipment, know-how and innovation that provides the project with a competitive advantage).

Another tactical function is risk mitigation. This NYTimes site is not the place to discuss confidential and legal matters that provide a project with protections against political risks.

In summary project financing works well if you have a professional team that knows the ins and outs of the project and how to structure the deal and how to move the free cash flow returns back to its rightful owners.

When we look at the universe through telescopes it is uniform, that is pretty much the same everywhere. But the universe is so large that the fastest possible thing, a beam of light, can only get halfway across it in the time it has existed. This means that no process could have made it uniform. It either had to start out uniform or something else had to happen. We know it did not start out uniform therefore something else had to happen.

Inflation is the something else. It allows a signal to cross the entire early universe, when it was the size of a grapefruit, at greater than the speed of light. This creates the observed uniformity without violating the current laws of nature. Because the current laws of nature did not exist when inflation happened.

The simplest way to understand this is that the Big Bang theory did not successfully predict the universe we observe. Inflation theory is just an ad hoc modification of the Big Bang to make it 'come out right'.

Any sanctions that have real bite--not attempted so far--will have to come from Europe. The U.S. does not trade enough with Russia for our sanctions to hurt the Russian economy. Europe CAN hurt the Russian economy with real sanctions if they're willing to take their own economic risks. European-Russian trade is a much bigger part of the Russian economy than it is the European economy. So Russia will hurt much more. The only hitch is Europe's dependence on Russian energy. Perhaps we can work to relieve that. I hope the U.S. has people working behind the scenes to help Europe with energy security with as little time gap as possible, especially before the next heating season.

I also hope it does not take Putin invading Eastern Ukraine to get the EU countries to get behind real sanctions that bite. The population of the "mainland" of Eastern Ukraine, with major cities such as Kharkiv & Donetsk, may lean Russian. But their national & political preferences are much more mixed than the population of Crimea. A Russian move on Eastern Ukraine can get very ugly very fast. I fear for the people who live there, whatever their national and political leanings.
